metadata.title: A semiconductor-electrochemistry model for design of high-rate Li ion battery

10.1016/j.jechem.2019.04.018 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig 1 Schematic diagram of our semiconductor-electrochemistry model: active materials as electrode in a battery system. E f is the Fermi energy after interfacial equilibrium, E f(sub) means the Fermi energy of substrate materials, E f(act) represents the Fermi energy of active materials, E f(o/x) denotes the Fermi energy of electrolyte near the surface of active materials (the same as chemical potential). Ox/Rd is the interface state density of electrolyte. Conduction band and valence band are referred to as the bands of active materials. Noting that E sub, E act and E ele are not the same, which just means that there is no charge transferring. Fig 1 Fig 2 Schematic diagram of the semiconductor-electrochemistry model: active materials applied with a negative voltage. E f1 means the Fermi energy free of an extra voltage, E f2 is the Fermi energy at a negative voltage, E f′ is the bend of band at the reaction interface. The equation (left) is seen in Eq. (3) and the equation (right) is shown in Eq. (4). Ec(h k l) (E c1, E c2,...,E c n ) is the splitting band levels, based on different planes of one crystal. Fig 2 Fig 3 Schematic diagram of the semiconductor-electrochemistry model: active materials applied with a negative voltage at the interface between active materials and electrolyte. Ec(h k l) means the splitting band of conduction band based on the different planes of a crystal. For Eqs. (5)–(9), M area means the active materials, ReM area means the M after lithiation, SEI area is the SEI film between active materials and electrolyte, and Int area means the electrolyte near the surface of active materials. μ 1, μ 2 and μ 3 are the Li ion migrations of these interphases, respectively. Fig 3 Fig 4 Schematic diagram of tailoring bad gap via (a) reducing sizes of active materials and (b) inducing defect or impurity (dopants), (c) high-resolution TEM image of defects in a layer LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 electrode. (d) Electrochemical performance and SEM image at different cutoff voltages. Copyright 2017, the authors and NPG [36]. Fig 4 Fig 5 (a) Schematic diagram of anti-T-shaped graphene coating of nanocrystralline active materials derived hypothesis via this model, (b) anti-T-shaped graphene interface coating of carbon paper for Li ion storage, the left in (b) shows fast ion channel for Li ion, and the right shows the large contact area for graphene coating. Copyright 2017, the authors and ACS [42]. Fig 5 Table 1 List of symbols. State Key Laboratory of Chem/Bio-Sensing and Chemometrics Provincial Hunan Key Laboratory for Graphene Materials and Devices College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Hunan University Changsha Hunan 410082 China. For designing batteries with high-rate and long-life, electronic/ionic transport and reaction must be unified for metal oxide electrodes. However, it remains challenging for effectively integrating the whole substrate/active materials/electrolyte interfaces. Herein by taking Li ion battery as example, we propose a semiconductor-electrochemistry model by which a general but novel insight has been gained into interfacial effect in batteries. Different from those traditional viewpoints, this derived model lies across from physics to electrochemistry. A reaction driving force can be expressed in terms of Fermi energy change, based on the tradeoff between electronic and ionic concentration at the reaction interfacial region. Therefore, at thermodynamic-controlled interface I of substrate/electrode, increasing contact areas can afford higher activity for active materials. Whereas at kinetically-governed interface II of electrode/electrolyte or inside active materials, it is crucial to guarantee high-reaction Li ionic concentration, with which some sufficient reaction degrees can reach. Graphical abstract Equivalent Fermi energy is related with the interfaces of substrate/active materials/electrolyte using semiconductor-electrochemistry theory, by which we can deepen the understanding of metal oxide as anode of Li ion battery. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Semiconductor electrochemistry Interface Surface Fermi energy SEI 1 Introduction Judged from Nernst equation or electrochemical kinetics equation, high electronic/ionic conduction is critical for high-performance battery. To obtain high rate-performance/energy-density batteries, the issues must be thereof addressed to reduce polarization and speed up charge exchange rate [1–4]. However, mechanistic clarification has been hampered by the lack of technically challenging high-resolution and in situ characterization. For instance, up to date Li ion battery cannot sufficiently meet the increasing high-performance demand. Undoubtedly, unraveling atomic-scale failure mechanism and real-time monitoring transport of ionic Li in active materials, e.g., via in situ state-of-the-art electrochemical microscopy/spectroscopy technique, will facilitate a direct design of high-performance Li ion batteries [5,6]. Therefore, there is a strong demand to deeply understand of transport and reaction issues covering the whole substrate/active materials/electrolyte interfaces, especially for metal oxide electrodes. Herein, we propose a novel model bridging from semiconductor to electrochemistry, coordinating thermodynamics with kinetics. Our model enables unifying the miscellaneous scenarios in Li ion battery towards ultimately improving the performance of Li ion batteries. Two interfaces are thereof involved. One is electronic transport at the substrate/active materials interface, and the other is referred to as ionic transport at the interface of active materials/electrolyte or inside active materials. Increasing contact areas can lead thereof to higher activity of active materials. Thus, it is crucial to guarantee high reaction ionic concentration. According to the splitting energy level of semiconductor band theory, a multiple reaction route occurs once the driving force as Fermi energy, controlled by ionic/electronic concentration, is higher than the splitting energy barriers. Therefore, dual functional interfaces of active materials, offered with high electronic/ionic transport, are beneficial for rate performance of electrodes, such as graphene coating via delicate sandwich or anti-T-shapes. For convenience, a list of symbols are shown in Table 1 . 2 Semiconductor-electrochemistry model Macroscopically we can treat two interfaces, one is between current collector/electrode and another is at electrode/electrolyte. However, an electrode commonly contains active materials, binder and conductive. Therefore, there exist the local differences because of complex states in the electrode. So a guideline is needed for battery design with addressing local interfacial issues. And it is well known that there are abundant interface/surface issues, e.g., interfacial impendence between active materials and electrolyte, interfacial phase in active materials, local concentration of electrolyte under the polarization, Li ion mobility of solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) film and active materials before/after the intercalation. However, the traditional electrochemical mechanism cannot unambiguously clarify the transport route of lithium ions, thereof enabling no identification of active interfaces. Thus, it has been not possible to ultimately address how to improve electrochemical performance of active materials. Metal oxides act as either common cathode or promising anode materials for Li ion battery; they are usually listed among semiconductor materials. Band theory is applicable to semiconductor materials. For the electrochemistry of semiconductors initialized in the 1960s, active materials can be treated as semiconductors consisting of conduction band, valence band and Fermi energy accordingly [7,8]. When an active material contacts with its substrate, a model of Schottky(-like) junction is suggested as either metal or graphene is usually treated as the substrate. The interface between active materials and electrolyte has been also understood with molecular orbital theory or density of states, with a similar macroscopical interfacial view [9,10]. That is to say, Fermi energy of electrolyte is regarded as chemical potential (see Fig. 1 ). Fermi energy of E sub, E act and E ele must locate in balance, free of any electronic or ionic transport if the system equilibrium reaches. It means that E sub, E act and E ele should proceed rarely with charge transferring, and self-discharge can be avoided without negative voltage in batteries. For a graphene/loaded metal oxide compositing electrode, E sub shifts beyond the conduction band under an applied negative voltage. Then an electrochemical reaction occurs. The charge transfer takes place in the contact area between active materials and graphene (see Fig. 2 ), according to the point charge electric potential (Eq. (1)). One can gain the contact potential η sub (Eq. (3)) [11]. Obviously, η sub is correlated with numbers of electron. Therefore, when charge is loaded into substrate, the highest occupied energy level of electron would be changed due to the potential energy of interfacial charge, just like the variation from E f1 to E f2 as shown in Fig. 2. Thus, E f is indirectly controlled by η sub; increasing S s affords an increase of η sub. As a consequence, E f shifts towards a deep conduction band. As the band energy theory is originated the electronic movement approximate theory, energy band enables being split into different energy levels. For a crystalline material, different crystal directions can be split into different energy levels according to electron sharing of direction-plane atoms. Therefore, it is very important to reduce the interface resistance in electrode for tailoring overpotential, such as electrode/current collector or active materials/conductive [12–14]. As shown in Figs. 2 and 3 , the different energy levels hold different energy barriers. An extra electrical field affects the magnitude E f, and the route of electron transport is directly controlled by E f. Based on our model, however, for the interface of active materials and electrolyte, there is an obvious changing band bend. Such occurrence is due to the fluctuation of SEI films and fresh reactants, originated from a continuously interfacial electronic/ionic transfer. The shift potential of interface between active materials and electrolyte can be analyzed with Nernst equation (Eq. (4)), where E re means the effective reduction potential, E φ is the standard reduction potential, R is universal gas constant (8.31 J K−1 mol−1), T is temperature, F is Faraday constant (9.65 × 104 C mol−1), and n is the transferred number of electrons. α re and α ox are the chemical activity for reductant and oxidant species, respectively (α = rC, where r and C are the coefficient and the concentration. As the ion concentration is low, r is close to 1, and C is approximately the same as α) [15]. Based on Eqs. (5 and 6), E f can be the initial interface potential, E f′ is an intermediate potential in the reaction process, and E 0 is the standard electrode potential. For this system, the reaction is limited by Li ion concentration (μ Li+<< μ e-). For the saturated α ox, α ox1 is the same as α ox2, and α Li +=C Li+ is gained (Eq. (7)). Therefore, as shown by Eq. (8) and Fig. 3, ΔE can be correlated with the change of C Li+. Fig. 3 indicates that E f can be tuned with the interfacial Li ion concentration, based on the principle E f′=E f –ΔE. In delithiation, the higher Li ion concentration enables tailoring of ΔE. Through promoting E f′ towards a deep band level in conduction band, the reaction is consequently enhanced. In contrast, as a lower Li ion concentration leads to higher reduction potential barrier, a larger ΔE causes E f′ down to the bottom of conduction band. E f′ is governed by the extra electric field and the interfacial C Li+. In other words, when E f′ is reduced into a slightly beyond the level of a facet energy band, there are only one reaction route and one pathway for Li ion transport. If E f′ exceeds more energy bands, a 3D reaction route can be a direction for Li ion transport, by which high rate reaction can occur. In another word, in the reaction interface the equivalent Fermi energy (E f ′) is dominated by the concentrations of electron (thermodynamics effect) and Li ion (kinetics effect). If E f′ is larger than Ecn , then there would be members of reaction routes. (1) η = k Q / r where η is the potential of a charge, k is the electrostatic force constant, Q means the quantity of charge, and r is the distance between this charge and the point charge. (2) Q s = i s S s (3) η sub = k i s S s / r where Q s denotes the quantity of charge between the active materials and substrate, e.g., graphene, i s means the current density, and S s represents the contact area. (4) E re = E φ − R T / n F × ln ( α re / α ox ) (5) E f = E o − R T / n F × ln ( C re1 / α ox1 ) (6) E f , = E o − R T / n F × ln ( C re2 / α ox2 ) (7) μ Li + < < μ e − ; α ox1 ≈ α ox2 (8) Δ E = E f − E f , = R T / n F × ln ( C re1 / C re2 ) (9) D Li + = μ Li + K T / q For Li ion battery, the exploration on the diffusion effect is always attractive [16]. For example, Eq. (9) is based on Einstein's relation (a kinetic theory, also known as Einstein–Smoluchowski relation) [17–19]. Here D Li+ means the diffusion coefficient of Li ions, K is Boltzmann's constant, T is the absolute temperature, and q is the electrical charge of one ion. μ Li+ means the mobility of Li ions. It is well known that C Li+ is correlated with D Li+. Fig. 3 shows that a higher μ Li+ of interphase leads to a higher concentration of Li ion. In Li ion batteries, the SEI film and the reactant/intercalation compound of Li (ReM in Fig. 3, suggesting the lithiation of active materials) may occur at the interface between active materials and electrolyte. Thus, μ Li+ comprises μ 1, μ 2 and μ 3 for ReM, SEI and surface electrolyte of active materials, respectively. Obviously, μ 1 is dominated by the active materials, μ 2 is controlled by the electrolyte and additives, and μ 3 is governed by the electrolyte. Therefore, an increase in μ 1, μ 2 and μ 3 leads to a high-performance battery [20,21]. Based on our semiconductor-electrochemistry model, one can summarize that the electrochemical performance of active materials of Li ion battery depends on a competitive mechanism: the interface between active materials and substrate is mainly controlled by thermodynamics mechanism; the interface between active materials and electrolyte is governed by kinetics mechanism. Further analyzing this model, it can be found that such balancing mechanism offers a controllable E f. Guided with the energy band split by different crystal planes, E f can be accordingly tuned with a variety of energy band barriers. Therefore, the increasing contact area and Li ion concentration in reaction interface not only increase possible electron transport channels, which may bring fast electrochemical response, but also enhance the reaction driving force, e.g., the works on reducing polarization by increasing electronic conductivity of substrate [12,13]. 2.1 Roadmap to high-performance Li ion electrode For thermodynamics effect of active materials, a lower polarization may induce a higher rate performance [22]. Generally speaking, there are two routes for lower polarization. One lies at enhancing surface conductivity of active materials, however, the surface reaction cannot enter deep into active materials. The other is to tailor the band gap of active materials. For example, the band gap can be reduced by nanostructuring of the active materials, as shown in Fig. 4 (a) [23]. However, it may fail easily due to an agglomeration of nanoscale materials [24,25]. Therefore, it has been widely accepted that high-rate electrode can be obtained via hybrids containing a dimension-reduced active materials for suppressing the agglomeration [26,27]. Furthermore, it can also tailor band gap via doping defects or heteroatoms into the lattice, relocating defect energy or doping energy level between the band gaps (Fig. 4b) [28,29]. Obviously, the doping energy level should offer a narrow band gap to lower the polarization. Defect electrochemistry has been widely accepted in photoelectric and electro-catalysis field [30]. In Li ion battery, to induce a defect energy level in carbon-based substrates can increase the conductivity of substrate and enhance Li adsorption and diffusion [31–33]. Meanwhile, to induce defect energy level in active materials may speed up Li ion transport and stabilize some lithiated compounds, and so on [34,35]. Recently, Yan et al. has demonstrated that the failure mechanism of layered LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 by using advanced transmission electron microscopy, lies at crack incubation in the interphase of active materials. Although a higher cutoff voltage can afford more capacity, an electrode failure may occur faster. Therefore, it is critical to select a suitable cutoff voltage for practical application, as shown in Fig. 4(c and d) [36]. Benefited from our model, defects in active materials induced a defect energy level, which may result in local electron gathering. If the barriers are lower than those of guest materials, a different reaction may occur. It became even worse if the defect phase is irreversibly transformed. Thereby, the route for overcoming this problem lies in controlling of applied voltage for tailoring E f. Meanwhile, it is suggested to reversibly promote defect phase in active materials, which can also lead to a long-life battery. As a consequence, it can induce faster reactions if the defect energy level shifts below the energy band of guest materials with a lower energy barrier. Therefore, it is worth mentioning that the induced energy level not only requires a narrow band gap, but also should meet high reversibility. In terms of designing a battery, a controllable voltage means some reversibly assigned reaction routes. For the kinetics effect of active materials, as mentioned above, the interfacial reaction depends mainly on the interfacial Li ion concentration. If the polarization applied on active materials is beyond the energy levels, electrons transport occurs via these crystalline planes. Therefore, a multiple reaction route can be offered. Unfortunately, in the deep reactive interface of active materials, Li ion concentration is determined by Li ion migration. The lower Li ion concentration around the reactive interface leads to more polarized voltage. Therefore, the capacity of a battery depends on the cut-off voltage at specified conditions. However, high voltage may result in the failure of a battery. On the basis of such trade-off mechanism, the road for designing high-rate Li ion battery lies in two key issues: the lager contact area between active materials and substrate, and the increasing surface/interfacial Li ion concentration in the reaction. Since graphene offers high electron/ion migrations, the electrochemical performance can be thereof largely improved when nanosacle active materials are loaded onto graphene. Furthermore, a graphene coating of active materials may afford more contact area and optimize Li ion concentration at the electrode/electrolyte interface. All of these merits can largely enhance rate performance. Unfortunately, the kinetics effect is complicatedly dominated by a variety of factors, such as ion transport in electrolyte, SEI film and active materials. In particular, it is hard to elaborate on SEI film. Thus, enhancing individual ionic mobility contributes to high-rate for electrode. Further elaboration on interfacial information is urgently needed for active materials during real-time lithiation/delithiation, e.g., in situ electrochemical TEM can be powerful to unravel such occurrence [37,38]. As a result, our proposed model can pinpoint more details of scenarios. 2.2 Guiding way and a hypothesis via this model From this proposed model, we can gain an insight into mechanistic electrochemical performance of active materials; two interfaces are key points, interconnected by an equivalent Fermi energy as a reaction force. Therefore, three routes are listed below for optimizing electrode performance. Route 1: Increasing surface contact area. It means not only providing more possible reaction channels, but also can increase the reaction driving force with a reducing polarization with offer for improved rate performance. Route 2: Increasing local Li ion concentration. That means there would be enough Li ions in reaction interface, and suppress space charge stacking, which may avoid high over potential. Therefore, it would be a key issue to reduce interface resistance of SEI film because of deficient realization, limited characterization methods and fickle state. Route 3: On macroscopical level, the interfaces in current collectors/electrode and electrode/electrolyte can be understood by this model [12]. On the microscopic level, the interfaces in substrate/active materials and lithiation/delithiation materials can also be surveyed via this model [13]. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of a whole electrode would afford more accurate information by integral numbers of microscopic interfaces via this model, e.g., Gennady et al. recently proposed a new view on mechanism of the battery voltage by using semiconductor-electrochemical theory [39]. In addition, both industries and research institutions have been making efforts to prepare single crystalline ternary cathodes that hold better rate performance than polycrystals [40]. For a square array for single crystalline ternary cathode, fast ionic transport can be offered. Whereas chaotic ion channels suffer from restrained ionic transport for the polycrystalline cathode. Based on our model, although a larger single crystalline active material facilitates fast ionic transport, the band gap may be larger. Thus, the advantage of defect or doping atom may not be applicable. For this method, it factually sacrifices thermodynamics effect for gearing kinetics effect. Differently, interfacial modification can be a compatible route, e.g., a sandwich of graphene and active materials [41]. Based on our recent work, anti-T-shaped graphene interface may induce maximal contact between active materials and substrate, as graphene coating can provide high electron exchange [42,43]. Moreover, the vertical multilayer graphene spacing can provide high ionic transport channel than traditional SEI films, as shown in Fig. 5 (a,b). Therefore, one can anticipate that graphene coating layers on the nanoscale active materials may forge more efficient electrode. 3 Outlook In short, we integrated thermodynamics (electric potential effect) and kinetics (ionic diffusion effect) issues, based on our proposed semiconductor-electrochemistry model and a variety of splitting band energy levels from crystal planes. We demonstrated that E f shifts under an extra electric field and at the interfaces abundant in Li ion concentration. Thus, the interface based electric field offers a thermodynamics shift; the interface based ionic diffusion is controlled by kinetic effect. Such occurrence is ascribed to the electrochemical processes in metal oxides for Li ion intercalation electrode. Meanwhile, these issues usually affect the performance of batteries. For instance, a higher extra electric field can shift E f to a higher energy level, whereas Li ion diffusion suppresses E f as the gathered space charge produces a reversible voltage. Such interdisciplinary view across from electrochemistry to semiconductor can address the relevance. That is to say, it attributes the electrochemical performance microscopically to the quantization of energy band levels. Our view based on semiconductor-electrochemistry model affords a direct strategy to obtain high-performance batteries. Increasing contact areas can afford higher activity of active materials. Meanwhile, it is crucial to guarantee a high reaction ionic concentration, with which high reaction activity can be also obtained. For Li ion battery, there are three types of interphases. A high rate electrode can be prepared via increasing their μ Li+. Notably, controlling applied potential can also lead to a suitable energy shift E f. As a result, Li ion transport/reaction may be more reversible through bypassing the irreversible reaction of interfacial defects inside the active materials. Therefore, it contributes to a long lifespan of electrodes. This concept can also functionalize if a positive charge into the substrate, in contrast with the mechanism described in Figs. 2 and 3. Meanwhile, other electrochemical reactions can also adopt our model, as it is mainly originated from the fundamental models of band energy theory and electrochemical theory. In addition, in-situ and real-time microscopy and spectroscopy are immediately needed to replenish and analyze atomic-scale electrochemical mechanism. Generally speaking, it is very urgent to work out a golden rule to design high-rate electrode via our mechanism model, which can be extended into a broad electrochemical application. Wei Zhang obtained his Ph.D. degree at Institute of Metal Research Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2004. He held positions in NIMS Japan, Samsung AIT, FHI of Max-Planck Society, DTU and CIC Energigune. He was awarded as IKERBASQUE Research Professor in 2016. In 2014 he became a full professor at Jilin University; since 2017 he has been also Acting Director of Electron Microscopy Center. His current research focuses on surface and interface of energy materials and catalysts. Dong Wang obtained his Bachelor at Henan University in 2008 and completed his Master's work in Southwest University of Science and Technology under guidance of Professor Bing Wang and Professor Ying Xiong in 2012. After 3-years work in a battery company, he obtained his Ph.D. degree at Jilin University in 2018 under guidance of Professors Weitao Zheng and Wei Zhang. Then he works as Assistant Professor in Hunan University in Yingpeng Wu research group for surface and interface of energy materials Weitao Zheng is Cheung Kong Distinguished Professor and Vice President of Jilin University. He obtained his Ph.D. degree at Jilin University in 1990. After that he held positions in Royal Institute of Sweden, Linköping University, Chiba Institute of Technology and Nanyang University of Technology. His current research focuses on energy materials, functional thin films and catalysts.

coredata.dc:description: For designing batteries with high-rate and long-life, electronic/ionic transport and reaction must be unified for metal oxide electrodes. However, it remains challenging for effectively integrating the whole substrate/active materials/electrolyte interfaces. Herein by taking Li ion battery as example, we propose a semiconductor-electrochemistry model by which a general but novel insight has been gained into interfacial effect in batteries. Different from those traditional viewpoints, this derived model lies across from physics to electrochemistry. A reaction driving force can be expressed in terms of Fermi energy change, based on the tradeoff between electronic and ionic concentration at the reaction interfacial region. Therefore, at thermodynamic-controlled interface I of substrate/electrode, increasing contact areas can afford higher activity for active materials. Whereas at kinetically-governed interface II of electrode/electrolyte or inside active materials, it is crucial to guarantee high-reaction Li ionic concentration, with which some sufficient reaction degrees can reach.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: A semiconductor-electrochemistry model for design of high-rate Li ion battery
